Indian National Congress' forty second annual session. It was resolved to boycott the Statutory Commission which the British Government had appointed "in utter disregard of India's right of self-determination."

A committee, headed by Motilal Nehru, was entrusted with the task of determining the principles of the Constitution. The report, known as the Nehru Report, was published in August. Its call for Dominion Status with full responsible government evoked a mixed response but was adopted by the Conference and received Gandhi's qualified support.
Viceroy, Lord Irwin, after a four month visit to England, announced a proposal for a Round Table Conference of British and Indian statesmen to meet in London to air the views of the various parties.

On 31 October he added: In view of the doubts which have been expressed both in Britain and India regarding the interpretation to be placed on the intentions of the British Government in enacting the statute of 1919, I am authorised on behalf of His Majesty's Government to state clearly that in their judgement, it is implicit in their declaration of 1917 that the natural issue of India's constitutional progress as there contemplated, is the attainment of dominion status.

Meeting between Gandhi and the Viceroy. Gandhi asked the Viceroy if the proposed Round Table Conference would proceed on the basis of full Dominion Status. The Viceroy's non-assurance led to the failure of the meeting. Gandhi headed for Lahore

At the Lahore Congress, the scheme of the Nehru Committee's Report was declared to have lapsed and in line with the Calcutta resolutions of the year before, it was declared that "the word 'Swaraj' in article one of the Congress constitution shall mean Complete Independence" and that the Congress "hopes that all Congressmen will henceforth devote their exclusive attention to the attainment of complete Independence for India."
The plan of action was to include boycotting elections, resignation of government political positions and a zealous prosecution of the constructive programme of the Congress.
Gandhi's eleven points published in Young India.
Congress Working Committee meets at Sabarmati Ashram, decision to launch Civil Disobedience campaign taken. Gandhi invested with full powers to launch the campaign as and when he thinks fit.

Gandhi wrote a long, detailed letter to the Viceroy which set out India's grievances as he saw them and proceeded to telegraph his punches in advance. It explained his reasons for breaking the salt law. It amounted to an ultimatum yet was addressed "Dear Friend".
After evening prayers at Ashram, Gandhi announces intention to march to Dandi.
Gandhi alongwith his band of followers commenced the Salt March from the Sabarmati Ashram.
At 6.30 am Gandhi sets out from Sabarmati Ashram with seventy-eight
Astali satyagrahis on the March to Dandi.
Dandi March: Evening halt at Astali
Day halt at Bareja. Evening halt at Navagam
Satish Kalelkar and Kharag Bahadur Singh join the first batch Marchers.
Day halt at Wasna. Evening halt at Matar.
Day halt at Dabhan. Evening halt at Nadiad.
Day halt at Boriavi. Evening halt at Anand,
Day halt at Napa. Evening halt at Borsad.
Day halt at Ras. Evening speech at Kankapura. The crossing of the river Mahi Sagar during night of 19/20 March.
AICC meeting at Ahmedabad confirms Working Committee resolution of February 14-16.
March day halt at Gajera. Evening halt at Ankhi.
Gandhi meets with AICC delegates. Motilal Nehru donates Anand Bhavan to Congress.
Day halt at Jambusar. Evening halt at Amod.
Day halt at Buva. Evening halt at Samni.
Day halt at Tralsa. Evening halt at Derol
Day halt at Broach. Evening halt at Ankleshwar.
Day halt at Sajod. Evening halt at Mangrol.
Day halt at Rayma. Evening halt at Umrachi.
Day halt at Ertham. Evening halt at Bhatgam.
Day halt at Sandhier. Evening halt at Delad.
Day halt at Chhaprabhata. Evening halt outside Surat. Mass meeting in Surat city
Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, Opposition Leader in Legislative Assembly, resigns his seat.
March day halt at Dindoli. Evening halt at Vanz.
Day halt at Dhaman. Evening halt at Navsari.
\Vijalpur, Matwad _ [Day halt at Vijalpur. Evening halt at Matwad.
Dandi Marchers arrive and spend the day at Dandi.
At 6.30 am Gandhi breaks Salt Law at Dandi. Commencement of the
Gandhi starts touring villages by car and increasing his speaking commitments.
Women's Conference at Dandi where Gandhi tells women that their time to take full share in the struggle has come. Salt Satyagraha was started at 27 different centres in Bihar.
Gandhi's headquarters moved from Dandi to Karadi.
Raid on the police armoury at Chittagong
Mass demonstrations commence in Peshawar. Mahadev Desai arrested.
In Peshawar Royal Garhwali Rifles refuse to fire on demonstrators.
Police and military withdrwan from Peshawar: town in the hands of the citizens until 4 May. Vithalbhai Patel resigns Presidentship of the Central Legislative Assembly.
Gandhi publicly announces raids on Dharasana in speech at Chharwada village.
Gandhi drafts a letter to Irwin informing the Viceroy of the intended raids on Dharasana.
Gandhi arrested at 0:45 am at Karadi.Taken to Yeravda Prison in a bus. Gave interview to The Daily Telegraphat Borivli on way to Poona.
Several of the original Marchers, under the leadership of Abbas Tyabji, commence march towards Dharasana snd are arrested.
Volunteers under the leadership of Sarojini Naidu marchh on the Dharasana salt-works.
Raids on salt-works at Wadala, near Bombay, commenced.
Sarojini Naidu arrested during mass raids at Dharasana.
Police raid satyagrahis camp at Untadi near Dharasana.
Mass raids on Wadala salt-works. Untadi camp destroyed by police.
Final raid on the Dharasana salt-works. Further such activity suspended.
